text:
Hmmm...other sources have the U.S. Gini coefficient at around 0.39, not the 0.48 that this says: https://data.oecd.org/inequality/income-inequality.htm

OECD and the Census bureau both seem like reputable sources, so I wonder what the methodology difference is.

A quick google shows the same thing is true in France and China. Those were the first two arbitrary countries that came to mind.

This seems to be a non story explained away by globalization or at least only of interest when discussed in the context of globalization as the trend seems to have little to do with the “US” specifically.
